article:
A 'hit and run' is a high risk/high reward offensive strategy used in baseball.
It uses a stolen base attempt to try to place the defending infielders out of
position for an attempted base hit.

The hit and run relies on the positioning of the defensive players in the
infield. The 1st and 3rd basemen normally stand close to the lines, generally
near their bases but slightly closer to home plate. The 2nd baseman and
shortstop stand on either side of 2nd base, covering the areas between 1st and
2nd, and 2nd and 3rd, respectively. 2nd base itself is not directly covered, the
pitcher can field hits in this direction.

In normal play, if the ball is hit in the infield one of the players will run
towards the ball while another will run towards the base that is no longer
covered. For instance, if the ball is hit toward the 2nd baseman he will run
towards the ball, and the shortstop will run towards 2nd base. This allows the
fielding player to toss the ball to the player on the base to attempt the "out".

However, during a stolen base attempt this normal turn of events and positioning
may be upset. In the typical case, a baserunner on first base will start running
towards second, causing the infielders to move towards the base in an attempt to
tag the runner when the ball is thrown to them from the pitcher or catcher. This
reaction places the infielders out-of-position for a hit ball, with holes
opening mid-way between 1st and 2nd and 2nd and 3rd.

The hit and run takes advantage of this by having the baserunner attempt to
steal as soon as the pitch is thrown. The batter then attempts to hit the ball
into the developing holes in the field. Ideally, the ball will be hit into a
gap, and travel into the outfield allowing the runners lots of time to reach
the bases.

Depending on the timing, the fielder may not have moved very far from their
normal position by the time the ball is hit towards them. But even in this case,
the fielder may have turned to run towards the base in order to cover the
baserunner. In normal play the fielders would face the batter, allowing them to
react in any direction, but after they have turned towards the base this becomes
much more difficult. Their momentum in this direction adds to this problem.

The hit and run also has defensive qualities. In normal play the baserunner
would start towards second base when the ball was hit. If the defensive
players react fast enough, they may be able to throw the ball to 2nd and 1st
before either runner has reached their base, causing a double play. In the
case of the hit and run, the baserunner has a huge head start, so the chance
of them reaching 2nd base after the ball is reduced. The timing may force the
fielders to attempt the out only at 1st, thereby advancing the runner. It may
also allow the runner to advance more bases on a hit than he might otherwise
due to that running head start. Although a line drive can easily turn into a
double play, line drives are rare so the risk to getting doubled off from a
line drive is minimal.

The risk in the hit and run is that if the batter fails to make contact with the
ball the runner is vulnerable to being thrown out (technically caught stealing)
at second base. A runner trying to advance on a failed hit-and-
run is more likely to be thrown out than a runner attempting a "straight steal"
of second, because the runner is not waiting for the best pitch to steal on, and
does not get the best head start on the way there because he waits a bit longer
at the original base to preserve the deception a while longer. The
defensive team can improve their odds in this case by using a pitchout, having
the pitcher throw the ball far outside the strike zone so the fielder can easily
catch it and attempt to pick off the runner.

The batter may choose to take a bad swing at a bad pitch to make it harder for
the catcher to handle the incoming pitch, or so the ball goes foul. In each case
the runner is allowed to return to 1st, so the attempt protects the runner from
being caught stealing. Either way, this can cause the batter to fall behind in
the count, making it harder for him to get a hit. And if he does hit a bad pitch
he really can't handle, it could result in poor contact leading directly to the
batter being put out, so he may end up giving his at-bat away with no advantage
to the offense.

The hit-and-run has the best chance to be successful when the batter is someone
who does not frequently swing and miss, at a time when the count won't
disadvantage a hitter if he takes a bad swing, with a runner fast enough to take
second base even if the batter does swing and miss.

Often the precise circumstance to call for a hit-and-run occurs with a two
balls, one strike count on a hitter, as this situation may meet all of the above
criteria, depending on who is at bat and who is on base, but it can occur at
other times. An alert defense understands the probability that the offense will
call the play at a specific moment, and thus it may choose to call for a
pitchout at that moment to defend it. An alert offense, in turn, understands the
probability of a forthcoming pitchout, and use the hit-and-run opportunity as a
decoy, causing the pitchout to become another ball in the count in the hitter's
favor, increasing his chances of reaching base by walk or hit.

The hit-and-run is a very old baseball strategy, dating back to the 19th century
game. The terminology is confusing because the "run" starts before
the "hit". And a variant of the hit-and-run is the run-and-hit, in which the
runner takes off on a steal attempt of second and the batter has the option of
whether or not to swing at the pitch.

The hit and run is so effective that defence against it is now an automatic part
of fielding. Generally the 2nd baseman and shortstop will cover the hit and run
possibility by having the fielder closest to the batter's strong arm be in
charge of covering the base. For instance, if the batter is right-handed, the
2nd baseman will be in charge of covering stolen bases, as the batter will
likely send the ball towards the shortstop. Likewise, the shortstop is in charge
of covering stolen bases when a lefty is on plate.
